column4: U.S. ITC to probe some cellular devices made by Samsung, Motorola Mobility
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. International Trade Commission on Tuesday said it was probing certain LTE-compliant cellular devices made by Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and Lenovo Group Ltd-owned Motorola Mobility following a complaint.
column6: The agency said it was launching the investigation following a Feb. 1 complaint filed by Austin, Texas-based Evolved Wireless LLC that alleged patent infringement.

column4: UK watchdog provisionally finds Motorola, Sepura broke competition law
column5: (Reuters) - British telecom regulator Ofcom said on Friday an investigation has provisionally found that communication firms Motorola and Sepura broke competition law during a procurement exercise run by UK police services partner Police ICT Company in 2018.
column6: Ofcom said the exchange of competitively sensitive information in relation to future pricing strategy between senior employees of the two firms restricted competition in the supply of Tetra devices, accessories and services for use on Britain's private communications network Airwave. (refini.tv/37yFhxJ)
column7: The watchdog, which issued a statement of objection, said Motorola Solutions and privately-held Sepura Limited can now make representations to Ofcom, which it will consider before taking a final decision.

column4: Motorola Solutions wins $764.6 million verdict in trade secrets case
column5: (Reuters) - Motorola Solutions Inc MSI.N said on Friday it had won a $764.6 million jury verdict in a trade secret theft and copyright infringement case against Chinese rival Hytera Communications Corp 002583.SZ.
column6: A U.S. jury in Chicago found Shenzhen-based Hytera used Motorola Solutions’ confidential documents and copyright-protected source code to compete in the market for two-way radio communications.
column7: Hytera, a former distributor of Motorola Solutions products, told jurors it had developed its radios on its own.
column8: The verdict was the maximum amount Motorola Solutions had asked jurors to award.
column9: Motorola Solutions said it was planning to seek an injunction preventing Hytera from further misappropriating trade secrets and infringing copyrights.
column10: “We presented clear facts and evidence of Hytera’s theft and infringement and are pleased the jury found in favor of our client,” said Michael De Vries, a Kirkland & Ellis lawyer representing the Chicago-based company, in a statement.
column11: Boyd Cloern, a lawyer for Hytera, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
column12: Motorola Solutions has a separate U.S. lawsuit pending against Hytera alleging patent infringement. A trial in this case is expected in late 2020 or early 2021, the U.S. company said.
column13: Hytera has its own pending U.S. lawsuit against Motorola Solutions alleging the company used intellectual property litigation and its market power to stifle competition.

column4: Motorola wins $764.6 mln in damages against Hytera Communications
column5: Feb 14 (Reuters) - Motorola Solutions Inc said on Friday it has won a trade secret theft and copyright infringement case against Chinese rival Hytera Communications Corp and has been awarded $764.6 million in damages.
column6: A U.S. jury in Chicago found that Hytera stole Motorola’s trade secrets and infringed its copyrights, the company said.
column7: Following the verdict, the communications device maker is planning to seek a global injunction preventing Hytera from further misappropriating the stolen trade secrets and infringing its copyrights. (Reporting by Amal S in Bengaluru and Jan Wolfe in Washington; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)
